questions.text: A woman with gestational diabetes mellitus is admitted to the labour room. The delivery of the baby's shoulder is delayed after the delivery of the head. When is shoulder dystocia considered?

choices.text: Head to shoulder delivery time >30 sec
Head to shoulder delivery time >45 sec
Head to shoulder delivery time >60 sec
Head to shoulder delivery time >120 sec

questions.solution:
Shoulder dystocia is defined as head to shoulder delivery time of more than 60 seconds. It occurs when either the anterior or the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively. 

Prelabour risk factors: 

  • Diabetes Mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Postdatism and prior history
  • Excessive weight gain during pregnancy

Intrapartum risk factors:

  • Prolonged 1st and 2nd stage of labour
  • Instrumental delivery
  • Augmentation of labour with oxytocin

questions.text:
A 25-year-old primigravida with a history of gestational diabetes mellitus is in active labour. After delivery of the head, turtle sign was noticed. Which of the following can be used for the management of this patient?
  1. Mc Robert's maneuver
  2. Wood's corkscrew maneuver
  3. Modified Ritgen's maneuver
  4. Rubin's maneuver
  5. Pinard's maneuver
  6. Gaskin's maneuver
questions.solution:
A patient with gestational diabetes and the presence of turtle sign is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Mc Robert's manoeuvre, Wood's corkscrew manoeuvre, Gaskin's manoeuvre, and Rubin's manoeuvre are all used in its management. 

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal pelvis. Turtle sign may be seen which refers to the recoil of the fetal head against the perineum.

Management of labour in case of shoulder dystocia:

  • 1st line of management - Mc Roberts manoeuvre (flexion and abduction of thigh)
  • 2nd line of management - Rubin's (rotation of the easily accessible shoulder by 30-45°), Woods corkscrew manoeuvre (rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a cork screw fashion) ; OR Gaskin (all four's position)
  • Last line of management - Zavanelli manoeuvre (head is rotated to its pre-restitution position and caesarian section is performed); OR procedures such as cleidotomy (fracture of the clavicle of the baby); symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother)

In a case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform cesarean section after doing Zavanelli manoeuvre.

questions.text: The first manoeuvre for shoulder dystocia consists of:

choices.text: Forceful adduction by extension of legs on abdomen
Forceful adduction by flexion of legs on abdomen
Forceful abduction of legs by extending them on abdomen
Forceful abduction of legs by flexing them on abdomen

questions.solution: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Mc Roberts manoeuvre is the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. It involves flexion and abduction of the maternal hips, positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen.

questions.text: A G2P1 obese woman was diagnosed with arrest of descent during labour. Identify the following manoeuvre performed for this patient.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and the manoeuvre shown above is the McRoberts manoeuvre. This is the most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. 

McRoberts manoeuvre:

  • Flexion and abduction of the maternal hips (positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen).
  • The pelvic rotation which occurs due to the straightening of the sacrum tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder of the baby. 
  • Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre.

If the first line of management fails, proceed with internal rotational manoeuvres such as Rubin's and Wood corkscrew in McRoberts position.

Rubin's manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the easily accessible shoulder towards the anterior aspect of the chest from under the pubic symphysis by 30-45° while staying in the McRoberts' position. 
  • Pressure is applied on the scapular aspect (posteriorly) of the shoulder.

Wood corkscrew manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the posterior shoulder by 180° in a corkscrew fashion to lie beneath the pubic symphysis while staying in McRobert's position.
  • Pressure is applied on the clavicular aspect (anteriorly) of the shoulder.

questions.text: Which of these steps would you undertake for the management of a patient with shoulder dystocia along with performing the McRoberts manoeuvre?

choices.text: Flex the legs over the abdomen

questions.solution:
Applying a gentle suprapubic pressure is the first step in the management of shoulder dystocia along with McRoberts manoeuvre. Fundal pressure is not a method of delivery in such cases.

Hernandez and Wendel suggested the use of a shoulder dystocia drill to better organize emergency management:

  • Call for help and mobilize labour assistants, anaesthesia and pediatric doctors.
  • An attempt at traction is tried followed by episiotomy to afford room posteriorly.
  • Apply pressure suprapubically, not fundally, with the palm or fist, directing the pressure on the anterior shoulder.
  • This should be both downward (below the pubic bone) and laterally (toward the baby's face or sternum) in conjunction with the McRoberts manoeuvre. 

These manoeuvres will resolve most cases of shoulder dystocia. If the above-listed steps fail, the following steps may be attempted, and any of the manoeuvres may be repeated:

  • Rubin's manoeuvre
  • Woods corkscrew manoeuvre
  • Gaskin (all four's position)
  • Zavanelli manoeuvre
  • Cleidotomy (fracture of the clavicle of baby) 
  • Symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother).

questions.text: What is the most common fetal malpresentation?
questions.solution:
The most common fetal malpresentation is the breech presentation.

The most common breech presentation in primigravida is frank breech and in multigravida, it is flexed/complete breech. It is most commonly seen with prematurity.

In breech presentation:

  • The most common position is left sacroanterior 
  • The engaging diameter is bitrochanteric.
  • Cord prolapse is common in footling presentation and rare in frank breech.

However, among all malpresentations, cord prolapse is most common in transverse lie.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is Vagos method used?
questions.solution:
Vagos method is used in cord prolapse.

Vagos method is also known as the bladder filling method. Here, the bladder is distended with saline to push the presenting part higher up, thereby preventing compression in case of cord prolapse. The bladder is filled with 400–750 mL of normal saline with a Foley’s catheter. Then, the balloon is inflated and the catheter is clamped.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with the following fetal presentation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of frank breech.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Breech type Description Presenting part
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Thighs flexed on the trunk, legs extended at the knee joint. Buttocks and genitalia
Footling Both thighs and legs are partially extended Foot 
Knee  Thighs extended, Knee flexed Knee
Complete/flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed. Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: A multigravida presented to the clinic at 36 weeks of gestation.  She was found to have a breech presentation clinically and on sonography.  Which of the following is not an indication for cesarean section in this type of presentation?
questions.solution:
Flexed breech is not an indication for cesarean section in breech presentation. This baby can be delivered vaginally.

Factors favouring cesarean delivery of the breech fetus:

  • Large fetus (> 3800 to 4000 g)
  • Severe IUGR
  • Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse)
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Previous cesarean section
  • Preterm breech
  • Primi with breech
  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech
  • Lack of surgeon experience
  • Patient requests for cesarean delivery.

questions.text: A footling breech comes under ______ type of breech presentation.
questions.solution:
A footling breech is a type of incomplete breech presentation with one or more feet below the breech.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete: Breech with extended legs, footling or knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Breech type Description Presenting part
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Thighs flexed on trunk, legs extended at knee joint. Buttocks and genitalia
Footling Both thighs and legs are partially extended Foot 
Knee  Thighs extended, knee flexed Knee
Complete/flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed. Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: A neonate is noted to have Klumpke's paralysis of the left arm following delivery. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the associated fetal presentation?
questions.solution:
Klumpke's paralysis is associated with difficult breech delivery, which is due to hyperabduction of the arm during traction and delivery of the fetus. Preeclampsia is not a risk factor for breech presentation.

Risk factors for breech presentation:  

  • Early gestational age
  • Abnormal amnionic fluid volume
  • Multifetal gestation
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Anencephaly
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Placenta previa
  • Fundal placental implantation
  • High parity with uterine relaxation
  • Prior breech delivery
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Smoking.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of the following presentation?
questions.solution:
The presentation depicted in the image is breech presentation. The most common cause of this presentation is prematurity.

The incidence of breech at term is 3%. At 28 weeks of pregnancy, 20% of women have a breech presentation. The fetus undergoes spontaneous version usually between 30 - 34 weeks thereby correcting its position by itself. 

Persistent breech occurs when this spontaneous version is prevented by any of the following causes:

  • Intrauterine death of the fetus
  • Anomalies such as trisomy 13, 18, 21
  • Anomalies of uterus (septate/bicornuate) 
  • Oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios
  • Twins
  • Short cord
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Placenta previa
  • Contracted pelvis

Recurrent/habitual breech is when breech recurs in 3 or more pregnancies. It is usually due to uterine anomalies and cornufundal attachment of the placenta.

questions.text: The following procedure is planned for a pregnant woman at 37 weeks of gestation. What is an absolute contraindication for this?
questions.solution:
Placenta previa is an absolute contraindication for external cephalic version (ECV).

Relative contraindications for ECV:

  • early labor
  • oligohydramnios  
  • ruptured membranes 
  • known nuchal cord
  • structural uterine abnormalities
  • fetal-growth restriction 
  • multifetal gestation 
  • prior abruption or its risk factors 
  • severe pre-eclampsia and hypertension
  • previous LSCS

Note:  In twin gestation, with a cephalic-noncephalic presentation, after the delivery of the first twin, an internal podalic version or intrapartum external cephalic version can be attempted for the second non-cephalic twin. However, ECV in this case, can lead to an increased incidence of fetal distress when compared with the internal podalic version. Hence, ECV is only a relative contraindication in twin pregnancy.

Previous LSCS is a relative contraindication for ECV. However, it is not attempted often and needs to be performed with caution.

questions.text: A multiparous woman presents in labour at 38 weeks of gestation.  On examination, the uterus appears asymmetrical and fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea. On fundal grip, the fetal pole is not palpable and in pelvic grip, the lower pole of the uterus is empty. What is the likely fetal presentation?
questions.solution:
The given examination findings are suggestive of transverse lie. The likely fetal presentation is shoulder presentation.

The most common cause of transverse lie is prematurity. In term pregnancy, it is commonly seen in patients with placenta previa. Although the most common cause of cord prolapse is transverse lie, hand prolapse is also frequently seen in such conditions. The transverse lie is managed by the caesarean section.

In a twin pregnancy, management of 1st twin with a transverse lie is caesarean section whereas the 2nd twin is managed by internal podalic version.

questions.text: An obstetrician is performing a breech delivery. Which of the following manoeuvres can be used for chin to pubis delivery?
questions.solution:
In a breech presentation, chin to pubis delivery can be done by Prague manoeuvre.

Rarely, the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the anterior. In such cases, rotation of the posteriorly oriented back of the fetus to the anterior may be achieved by using stronger traction on the fetal legs or bony pelvis.

If this still does not succeed, the fetus still may be delivered using the modified Prague manoeuvre. This consists of two fingers of one hand grasping the shoulders of the back-down fetus from below while the other hand draws the feet up and over the maternal abdomen.

If the back is oriented anteriorly, extraction may be accomplished using the Mauriceau manoeuvre and delivering the fetus back down.

  • If the fetal back is anterior - Mauriceau manoeuvre.
  • If the fetal back is posterior - Modified Prague manoeuvre. (Mnemonic: P for P)

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not used for delivery of the aftercoming head in breech?
questions.solution:
Delivery of the aftercoming head in breech is not done with the help of Keilland's forceps. These forceps are used for the rotation of the fetal head. It is not used anymore.

The methods used for delivery of the aftercoming head include the following:

Burns-Marshall manoeuvre: When the occiput is seen under the pubic symphysis, steady traction is given on the feet. The baby is swung in an arc towards the mother's abdomen. Simultaneous suprapubic pressure is given and the head is born by flexion.

Malar flexion and shoulder traction (modified Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique):

The baby is placed on the supinated left forearm (preferred) with the limbs hanging on either side. The middle and the index fingers of the left hand are placed over the malar bones. The ring and little fingers of the pronated right hand are placed on the child’s right shoulder. The index finger is placed on the left shoulder and the middle finger is placed on the suboccipital region.

Traction is now given in a downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch. The assistant gives suprapubic pressure during the period to maintain flexion. The fetus is carried in an upward and forward direction toward the mother’s abdomen releasing the face and brow. Lastly, the trunk is depressed to release the occiput and vertex.

The image below shows Piper's forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the management of entrapment of aftercoming head?
questions.solution:
The management of entrapment of aftercoming head does not involve Kristellar manoeuvre. 

Kristeller manoeuvre is the application of uterine fundal pressure during the second stage of labour to shorten the second stage of labour. This should be used sparingly used as it leads to avulsion of the levator ani.

An incompletely dilated cervix will constrict around the neck and impede the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech.

Management options:

With gentle traction on the fetal body, the cervix may be manually slipped over the occiput.

If this is not successful, then Dührssen incisions may be necessary. These are a set of three incisions in the cervix:

  • Can be made at the 2 and 10 o'clock position on the cervix. An additional incision at the 6 o’clock position is sometimes needed.
  • Done for delivery of aftercoming head in breech or delivery of head through an incompletely dilated cervix.
  • There is a significant risk of haemorrhage; the cervical incision may extend upwards within the broad ligament causing broad ligament haematoma.

Other alternatives include intravenous nitroglycerin, typically 100 μg, to provide cervical relaxation. General anaesthesia with halogenated agents is another option.

As a last resort, the following methods are used:

  • Zavanelli manoeuvre: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery. This is performed for the protruding head and intractable shoulder dystocia.
  • Symphysiotomy: The intervening symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis. It is also used to aid the delivery of an entrapped aftercoming head.

questions.text: A woman in labour presented to the ER. A vaginal breech delivery was planned for her. What statement regarding the management is false?

choices.text: Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for vaginal delivery
Breech delivery is done in an hospital where a facility for emergency cesarean delivery is available
Continous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labour
Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

questions.solution:
Breech identified for the first time during delivery is not a contraindication for normal delivery. 

Vaginal breech delivery is considered when:

  • Fetal weight is between 1.5 kg and 3.5 kg
  • There is an adequate pelvis
  • The presentation is frank breech
  • The fetal head is flexed
  • There are no medical or obstetric complications
  • Facilities for emergency cesarean section are available (anesthetists, neonatologists) (option B)
  • Facilities for continuous labor monitoring are available (option C)
  • A skilled obstetrician is present (option D)
  • Detailed informed consent has been obtained, explaining the risks of vaginal breech delivery

Cesarean delivery for breech presentation is considered in the following cases:

  • Lack of operator experience
  • Patient's request for cesarean delivery
  • Prior perinatal death or neonatal birth trauma
  • Large fetus: > 3800 to 4000 g
  • Severe IUGR, term weight <2.5kg to 2.8kg
  • Incomplete breech presentation
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Fetal anomaly incompatible with vaginal delivery
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Preterm breech
  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech position
 

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

Related Pearl: External cephalic version- indications and contraindications

External cephalic version (ECV) is done to bring the favourable cephalic pole in the lower pole of the uterus.

Indications:

  • Breech presentation
  • Tranverse lie

Contraindications:

  • APH due to risk of placental separation
  • Fetal causes- hyperextension of the neck ("star-gazing" position), large fetus (>3.5 kg), congenital abnormalities, dead fetus, fetal compromise
  • Obstetric complications- severe pre-eclampsia, obesity, elderly primigravida, bad obstetric history 
  • Rh alloimmunization
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Ruptured membrane
  • Congenital malformations of uterus
  • Abnormal CTG
  • Contracted pelvis

questions.text: On doing PV examination of a woman in labour, mouth with hard alveolar margins and malar eminence is palpable. Which of the following is not a cause of this fetal presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of face presentation. Gynecoid pelvis is not a cause of this fetal presentation.

Causes of face presentation: 

  • Anencephaly (most common cause)
  • Intrauterine death
  • Multiparity
  • Prematurity
  • Twist of cord around the neck
  • Anthropoid pelvis
  • Platypelloid pelvis
  • Tumours of neck of the fetus.

questions.text: A multiparous woman was admitted to the labour room at term with complaints of draining per vaginum.  On examination, the uterus corresponds to term size, presentation is cephalic and the presenting part is face.  Which diameter is engaged in this type of presentation?
questions.solution:
Engaging diameter in face presentation is submentovertical and submentobregmatic. 

Presentation Engaging diameter Measurement

Vertex (Complete flexion)

 Suboccipitobregmatic 9.5 cm
Vertex (Incomplete flexion) Suboccipitofrontal 10 cm
Vertex (Marked Deflexion) Occipitofrontal 11.5 cm
Face ( Incomplete extension) Submentovertical 11.5 cm
Face Submentobregmatic 9.5 cm
Brow Mentovertical

14 cm

questions.text: A G2P1 woman presented to the clinic at 40 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterus corresponds to term size and the fetal head is mobile. What is the most common cause to be suspected here?
questions.solution:
Occipitoposterior position (OP) is the most common cause of a mobile head at term.

It is the most common fetal malposition. It is an abnormal position seen in the vertex presentation, not an abnormal presentation.

  • Occipitoposterior position is commonly seen in android pelvis/deflexed head.
  • The engaging diameter of this position is sub-occipitofrontal/occipitofrontal.
  • The most common type in occipitoposterior position is right OP.
  • A persistent occipitoposterior position results from a failure of internal rotation prior to birth.

Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) is a disproportion in the size of the fetus relative to the maternal pelvis. This can result in the failure of progress of labour in the second stage. This usually occurs due to fetal malposition e.g., extended or asynclitic fetal head, occipitoposterior or transverse position. It is also seen in malpresentations like mentum posterior, brow.

The diagnosis of CPD is subjective. However, true CPD may occur if the fetus has a large anomaly e.g., teratoma or conjoined twin, or in cases of a large fetus. It can also occur when the maternal pelvis is small or deformed like after pelvic trauma.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 woman in labour was admitted to the hospital at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, the fetus was found to be in occipitoposterior position. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Wait and watch for progress of labour

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for pregnant women in labour whose fetus is in occipitoposterior position is to wait and watch for progress of labour. In a majority of cases, the occiput rotates through 3/8th of the circle and the baby is born as occipitoanterior.

Hence, when the diagnosis of occipitoposterior is made, labour is allowed to proceed normally when there are good uterine contractions and favourable pelvis.

Indications of caesarean section in occipitoposterior position:

  • Arrest of labour
  • Inadequate uterine contraction
  • Fetal distress
  • Other obstetrical indications.

questions.text: What is the most common complication seen in face to pubis delivery?
questions.solution:
The most common complication seen in face to pubis delivery is complete perineal tears.

In face to pubis delivery, the occiput is posterior, and therefore, the largest biparietal diameter (9.4 cm) distends the perineum rather than the smaller bitemporal diameter (8 cm). A liberal episiotomy helps to avoid perineal tears.

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm
